content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. The disparity in investment in education between the US and its trading partners is leading to declining educational performance in the US compared to other countries in a global marketplace. The current global workforce environment creates competitive pressures on US businesses to fund worker education and training, similar to other countries. It is crucial for the US government to reverse this trend to support national security, the middle class, and workers, while maintaining global competitiveness through public-private partnerships. The research and development tax credit under section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 maximizes sector strengths, reduces development risk, and improves cost effectiveness. Businesses are adept at training the workforce for available jobs and developing new training methods. The US needs to train its workforce for high-paying technology jobs to support retiring baby boomers and maintain competitiveness. The Act aims to encourage businesses and individuals to support the educational development of knowledge workers in the US by providing incentives for information and communications technology education and training investments. This includes retraining mature workers for new jobs after retirement. The Act also promotes training incumbent workers and potential employees to expand and maintain businesses effectively. The Act aims to support educational development and training investments for knowledge workers in the US, including retraining mature workers for new jobs and promoting training for incumbent workers and potential employees to enhance business effectiveness. This will help better utilize training dollars and maximize the ability of newly trained individuals to utilize their skills. The Act supports educational development and training investments for knowledge workers in the US, including retraining mature workers for new jobs and promoting training for incumbent workers and potential employees to enhance business effectiveness. Additionally, it introduces a new section, SEC. 30D, which focuses on Information and Communications Technology Education and Training Program Expenses. The Act introduces a new section, SEC. 30D, allowing a 50% tax credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses incurred by taxpayers for the benefit of employees or individuals. The credit is subject to limitations and coordination with employees assigning limitations to employers. The Act introduces a new section, SEC. 30D, allowing a 50% tax credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses incurred by taxpayers for the benefit of employees or individuals. The credit is subject to limitations where expenses for any individual cannot exceed $4,000, with a potential increase to $5,000 for certain programs and individuals in designated zones or communities. The Act allows a 50% tax credit for education and training program expenses related to information and communications technology. Eligibility criteria include students receiving free or reduced-cost lunches, living in disaster areas, or rural enterprise communities. The tax credit for education and training program expenses applies to areas designated as Rural Economic Area Partnership Zones, areas under Indian tribal government jurisdiction, or employers with 200 or fewer employees. The tax credit for education and training program expenses applies to individuals with disabilities. Information technology education and training program expenses include course work, certification testing, programs registered by the Department of Labor, and other essential expenses. The tax credit applies to individuals with disabilities for education and training program expenses, including course work, certification testing, and other essential expenses related to assessing skill acquisition in information technology. An information technology education and training program is defined as a training program in information and communications technology workplace disciplines provided by accredited institutions or commercial providers. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of an employer-owned information technology training organization and the denial of double benefits for expenses related to the education and training program. It specifies that no other deductions or credits are allowed for expenses considered for the credit under this section. The curr_chunk discusses the reduction of the amount for hope and lifetime learning credits by information technology education and training program expenses. Rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52 apply. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by other credits. The table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a clerical amendment. Sec. 30D outlines information and communications technology education and training program expenses. The effective date for the amendments made in this section applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2006. Additionally, Section 4 defines eligible educational institutions. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 expands the definition of eligible educational institutions to include institutions described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and commercial information and communications technology training providers. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 221(d)(2) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 5. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TRAINING CERTIFICATION ADVISORY BOARD. Establishment of Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. Board members must be associated with IT certification and training associations, not federal government employees. The Board meets at least annually and elects a Chairperson from its members who is a member of an IT industry trade association. The Board's duties include developing guidelines for computer technology. The Board is responsible for developing guidelines for computer science and information technology courses, as well as a list of approved IT training and certifications for tax credits. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Board submits the list to the Secretary of the Treasury annually. The Board, under subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, performs services away from their regular places of business. The termination of the Board is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
